-- | Defines a file system on a Network File System (NFS) server that can
--   be read from or written to.
module Network.AWS.DataSync.CreateLocationNfs

-- | CreateLocationNfsRequest
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateLocationNfs</a> smart constructor.
data CreateLocationNfs
CreateLocationNfs' :: Maybe NfsMountOptions -> Maybe [TagListEntry] -> Text -> Text -> OnPremConfig -> CreateLocationNfs

-- | The NFS mount options that DataSync can use to mount your NFS share.
[$sel:mountOptions:CreateLocationNfs'] :: CreateLocationNfs -> Maybe NfsMountOptions

-- | The key-value pair that represents the tag that you want to add to the
--   location. The value can be an empty string. We recommend using tags to
--   name your resources.
[$sel:tags:CreateLocationNfs'] :: CreateLocationNfs -> Maybe [TagListEntry]

-- | The subdirectory in the NFS file system that is used to read data from
--   the NFS source location or write data to the NFS destination. The NFS
--   path should be a path that's exported by the NFS server, or a
--   subdirectory of that path. The path should be such that it can be
--   mounted by other NFS clients in your network.
--   
--   To see all the paths exported by your NFS server, run "<tt>showmount
--   -e nfs-server-name</tt>" from an NFS client that has access to your
--   server. You can specify any directory that appears in the results, and
--   any subdirectory of that directory. Ensure that the NFS export is
--   accessible without Kerberos authentication.
--   
--   To transfer all the data in the folder you specified, DataSync needs
--   to have permissions to read all the data. To ensure this, either
--   configure the NFS export with <tt>no_root_squash,</tt> or ensure that
--   the permissions for all of the files that you want DataSync allow read
--   access for all users. Doing either enables the agent to read the
--   files. For the agent to access directories, you must additionally
--   enable all execute access.
--   
--   If you are copying data to or from your Snowcone device, see <a>NFS
--   Server on Snowcone</a> for more information.
--   
--   For information about NFS export configuration, see 18.7. The
--   /etc/exports Configuration File in the Red Hat Enterprise Linux
--   documentation.
[$sel:subdirectory:CreateLocationNfs'] :: CreateLocationNfs -> Text

-- | The name of the NFS server. This value is the IP address or Domain
--   Name Service (DNS) name of the NFS server. An agent that is installed
--   on-premises uses this host name to mount the NFS server in a network.
--   
--   If you are copying data to or from your Snowcone device, see <a>NFS
--   Server on Snowcone</a> for more information.
--   
--   This name must either be DNS-compliant or must be an IP version 4
--   (IPv4) address.
[$sel:serverHostname:CreateLocationNfs'] :: CreateLocationNfs -> Text

-- | Contains a list of Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) of agents that are
--   used to connect to an NFS server.
--   
--   If you are copying data to or from your Snowcone device, see <a>NFS
--   Server on Snowcone</a> for more information.
[$sel:onPremConfig:CreateLocationNfs'] :: CreateLocationNfs -> OnPremConfig

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateLocationNfs</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:mountOptions:CreateLocationNfs'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationNfs_mountOptions</a> - The NFS mount options that
--   DataSync can use to mount your NFS share.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateLocationNfs'</a>, <a>createLocationNfs_tags</a> -
--   The key-value pair that represents the tag that you want to add to the
--   location. The value can be an empty string. We recommend using tags to
--   name your resources.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subdirectory:CreateLocationNfs'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationNfs_subdirectory</a> - The subdirectory in the NFS
--   file system that is used to read data from the NFS source location or
--   write data to the NFS destination. The NFS path should be a path
--   that's exported by the NFS server, or a subdirectory of that path. The
--   path should be such that it can be mounted by other NFS clients in
--   your network.
--   
--   To see all the paths exported by your NFS server, run "<tt>showmount
--   -e nfs-server-name</tt>" from an NFS client that has access to your
--   server. You can specify any directory that appears in the results, and
--   any subdirectory of that directory. Ensure that the NFS export is
--   accessible without Kerberos authentication.
--   
--   To transfer all the data in the folder you specified, DataSync needs
--   to have permissions to read all the data. To ensure this, either
--   configure the NFS export with <tt>no_root_squash,</tt> or ensure that
--   the permissions for all of the files that you want DataSync allow read
--   access for all users. Doing either enables the agent to read the
--   files. For the agent to access directories, you must additionally
--   enable all execute access.
--   
--   If you are copying data to or from your Snowcone device, see <a>NFS
--   Server on Snowcone</a> for more information.
--   
--   For information about NFS export configuration, see 18.7. The
--   /etc/exports Configuration File in the Red Hat Enterprise Linux
--   documentation.
--

--   <a>createLocationNfs_serverHostname</a> - The name of the NFS server.
--   This value is the IP address or Domain Name Service (DNS) name of the
--   NFS server. An agent that is installed on-premises uses this host name

--   Server on Snowcone</a> for more information.

--   location. The value can be an empty string. We recommend using tags to
--   name your resources.

-- | The subdirectory in the NFS file system that is used to read data from

--   belongs to.

-- | Creates an endpoint for an Amazon EFS file system.
module Network.AWS.DataSync.CreateLocationEfs

-- | CreateLocationEfsRequest
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateLocationEfs</a> smart constructor.
data CreateLocationEfs
CreateLocationEfs' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe [TagListEntry] -> Text -> Ec2Config -> CreateLocationEfs

-- | A subdirectory in the location’s path. This subdirectory in the EFS
--   file system is used to read data from the EFS source location or write
--   data to the EFS destination. By default, DataSync uses the root
--   directory.
--   
--   <tt>Subdirectory</tt> must be specified with forward slashes. For
--   example, <tt>/path/to/folder</tt>.
[$sel:subdirectory:CreateLocationEfs'] :: CreateLocationEfs -> Maybe Text

-- | The key-value pair that represents a tag that you want to add to the
--   resource. The value can be an empty string. This value helps you
--   manage, filter, and search for your resources. We recommend that you
--   create a name tag for your location.
[$sel:tags:CreateLocationEfs'] :: CreateLocationEfs -> Maybe [TagListEntry]

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the Amazon EFS file system.
[$sel:efsFilesystemArn:CreateLocationEfs'] :: CreateLocationEfs -> Text

-- | The subnet and security group that the Amazon EFS file system uses.
--   The security group that you provide needs to be able to communicate
--   with the security group on the mount target in the subnet specified.
--   
--   The exact relationship between security group M (of the mount target)
--   and security group S (which you provide for DataSync to use at this
--   stage) is as follows:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Security group M (which you associate with the mount target) must
--   allow inbound access for the Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) on
--   the NFS port (2049) from security group S. You can enable inbound
--   connections either by IP address (CIDR range) or security group.</li>
--   <li>Security group S (provided to DataSync to access EFS) should have
--   a rule that enables outbound connections to the NFS port on one of the
--   file system’s mount targets. You can enable outbound connections
--   either by IP address (CIDR range) or security group.For information
--   about security groups and mount targets, see Security Groups for
--   Amazon EC2 Instances and Mount Targets in the <i>Amazon EFS User
--   Guide.</i></li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:ec2Config:CreateLocationEfs'] :: CreateLocationEfs -> Ec2Config

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateLocationEfs</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:subdirectory:CreateLocationEfs'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationEfs_subdirectory</a> - A subdirectory in the
--   location’s path. This subdirectory in the EFS file system is used to
--   read data from the EFS source location or write data to the EFS
--   destination. By default, DataSync uses the root directory.
--   
--   <tt>Subdirectory</tt> must be specified with forward slashes. For
--   example, <tt>/path/to/folder</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateLocationEfs'</a>, <a>createLocationEfs_tags</a> -
--   The key-value pair that represents a tag that you want to add to the
--   resource. The value can be an empty string. This value helps you
--   manage, filter, and search for your resources. We recommend that you
--   create a name tag for your location.
--   
--   <a>$sel:efsFilesystemArn:CreateLocationEfs'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationEfs_efsFilesystemArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) for the Amazon EFS file system.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ec2Config:CreateLocationEfs'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationEfs_ec2Config</a> - The subnet and security group
--   that the Amazon EFS file system uses. The security group that you
--   provide needs to be able to communicate with the security group on the
--   mount target in the subnet specified.
--   
--   The exact relationship between security group M (of the mount target)
--   and security group S (which you provide for DataSync to use at this
--   stage) is as follows:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Security group M (which you associate with the mount target) must
--   allow inbound access for the Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) on
--   the NFS port (2049) from security group S. You can enable inbound
--   connections either by IP address (CIDR range) or security group.</li>
--   <li>Security group S (provided to DataSync to access EFS) should have
--   a rule that enables outbound connections to the NFS port on one of the
--   file system’s mount targets. You can enable outbound connections
--   either by IP address (CIDR range) or security group.For information
--   about security groups and mount targets, see Security Groups for
--   Amazon EC2 Instances and Mount Targets in the <i>Amazon EFS User
--   Guide.</i></li>
--   </ul>
newCreateLocationEfs :: Text -> Ec2Config -> CreateLocationEfs

-- | A subdirectory in the location’s path. This subdirectory in the EFS
--   file system is used to read data from the EFS source location or write
--   data to the EFS destination. By default, DataSync uses the root
--   directory.
--   
--   <tt>Subdirectory</tt> must be specified with forward slashes. For
--   example, <tt>/path/to/folder</tt>.
createLocationEfs_subdirectory :: Lens' CreateLocationEfs (Maybe Text)

-- | The key-value pair that represents a tag that you want to add to the
--   resource. The value can be an empty string. This value helps you
--   manage, filter, and search for your resources. We recommend that you
--   create a name tag for your location.
createLocationEfs_tags :: Lens' CreateLocationEfs (Maybe [TagListEntry])

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the Amazon EFS file system.
createLocationEfs_efsFilesystemArn :: Lens' CreateLocationEfs Text

-- | The subnet and security group that the Amazon EFS file system uses.
--   The security group that you provide needs to be able to communicate
--   with the security group on the mount target in the subnet specified.
--   
--   The exact relationship between security group M (of the mount target)
--   and security group S (which you provide for DataSync to use at this
--   stage) is as follows:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Security group M (which you associate with the mount target) must
--   allow inbound access for the Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) on
--   the NFS port (2049) from security group S. You can enable inbound
--   connections either by IP address (CIDR range) or security group.</li>
--   <li>Security group S (provided to DataSync to access EFS) should have
--   a rule that enables outbound connections to the NFS port on one of the
--   file system’s mount targets. You can enable outbound connections
--   either by IP address (CIDR range) or security group.For information
--   about security groups and mount targets, see Security Groups for
--   Amazon EC2 Instances and Mount Targets in the <i>Amazon EFS User
--   Guide.</i></li>
--   </ul>

-- | Activates an DataSync agent that you have deployed on your host. The
--   activation process associates your agent with your account. In the
--   activation process, you specify information such as the Amazon Web
--   Services Region that you want to activate the agent in. You activate
--   the agent in the Amazon Web Services Region where your target
--   locations (in Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS) reside. Your tasks are created
--   in this Amazon Web Services Region.
--   
--   You can activate the agent in a VPC (virtual private cloud) or provide
--   the agent access to a VPC endpoint so you can run tasks without going
--   over the public internet.
--   
--   You can use an agent for more than one location. If a task uses
--   multiple agents, all of them need to have status AVAILABLE for the
--   task to run. If you use multiple agents for a source location, the
--   status of all the agents must be AVAILABLE for the task to run.
--   
--   Agents are automatically updated by Amazon Web Services on a regular
--   basis, using a mechanism that ensures minimal interruption to your
--   tasks.
module Network.AWS.DataSync.CreateAgent

-- | CreateAgentRequest
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateAgent</a> smart constructor.
data CreateAgent
CreateAgent' :: Maybe (NonEmpty Text) -> Maybe (NonEmpty Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [TagListEntry] -> Text -> CreateAgent

-- | The ARNs of the security groups used to protect your data transfer
--   task subnets. See <a>SecurityGroupArns</a>.
[$sel:securityGroupArns:CreateAgent'] :: CreateAgent -> Maybe (NonEmpty Text)

-- | The Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) of the subnets in which DataSync will
--   create elastic network interfaces for each data transfer task. The
--   agent that runs a task must be private. When you start a task that is
--   associated with an agent created in a VPC, or one that has access to
--   an IP address in a VPC, then the task is also private. In this case,
--   DataSync creates four network interfaces for each task in your subnet.
--   For a data transfer to work, the agent must be able to route to all
--   these four network interfaces.
[$sel:subnetArns:CreateAgent'] :: CreateAgent -> Maybe (NonEmpty Text)

-- | The name you configured for your agent. This value is a text reference
--   that is used to identify the agent in the console.
[$sel:agentName:CreateAgent'] :: CreateAgent -> Maybe Text

-- | The ID of the VPC (virtual private cloud) endpoint that the agent has
--   access to. This is the client-side VPC endpoint, also called a
--   PrivateLink. If you don't have a PrivateLink VPC endpoint, see
--   <a>Creating a VPC Endpoint Service Configuration</a> in the Amazon VPC
--   User Guide.
--   
--   VPC endpoint ID looks like this: <tt>vpce-01234d5aff67890e1</tt>.
[$sel:vpcEndpointId:CreateAgent'] :: CreateAgent -> Maybe Text

-- | The key-value pair that represents the tag that you want to associate
--   with the agent. The value can be an empty string. This value helps you
--   manage, filter, and search for your agents.
--   
--   Valid characters for key and value are letters, spaces, and numbers
--   representable in UTF-8 format, and the following special characters: +
--   - = . _ : / @.
[$sel:tags:CreateAgent'] :: CreateAgent -> Maybe [TagListEntry]

-- | Your agent activation key. You can get the activation key either by
--   sending an HTTP GET request with redirects that enable you to get the
--   agent IP address (port 80). Alternatively, you can get it from the
--   DataSync console.
--   
--   The redirect URL returned in the response provides you the activation
--   key for your agent in the query string parameter
--   <tt>activationKey</tt>. It might also include other activation-related
--   parameters; however, these are merely defaults. The arguments you pass
--   to this API call determine the actual configuration of your agent.
--   
--   For more information, see Activating an Agent in the /DataSync User
--   Guide./
[$sel:activationKey:CreateAgent'] :: CreateAgent -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateAgent</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:securityGroupArns:CreateAgent'</a>,
--   <a>createAgent_securityGroupArns</a> - The ARNs of the security groups
--   used to protect your data transfer task subnets. See
--   <a>SecurityGroupArns</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subnetArns:CreateAgent'</a>, <a>createAgent_subnetArns</a> -
--   The Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) of the subnets in which DataSync will
--   create elastic network interfaces for each data transfer task. The
--   agent that runs a task must be private. When you start a task that is
--   associated with an agent created in a VPC, or one that has access to
--   an IP address in a VPC, then the task is also private. In this case,
--   DataSync creates four network interfaces for each task in your subnet.
--   For a data transfer to work, the agent must be able to route to all
--   these four network interfaces.
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentName:CreateAgent'</a>, <a>createAgent_agentName</a> - The
--   name you configured for your agent. This value is a text reference
--   that is used to identify the agent in the console.
--   
--   <a>$sel:vpcEndpointId:CreateAgent'</a>,
--   <a>createAgent_vpcEndpointId</a> - The ID of the VPC (virtual private
--   cloud) endpoint that the agent has access to. This is the client-side
--   VPC endpoint, also called a PrivateLink. If you don't have a
--   PrivateLink VPC endpoint, see <a>Creating a VPC Endpoint Service
--   Configuration</a> in the Amazon VPC User Guide.
--   
--   VPC endpoint ID looks like this: <tt>vpce-01234d5aff67890e1</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateAgent'</a>, <a>createAgent_tags</a> - The key-value
--   pair that represents the tag that you want to associate with the
--   agent. The value can be an empty string. This value helps you manage,
--   filter, and search for your agents.
--   
--   Valid characters for key and value are letters, spaces, and numbers
--   representable in UTF-8 format, and the following special characters: +
--   - = . _ : / @.
--   
--   <a>$sel:activationKey:CreateAgent'</a>,
--   <a>createAgent_activationKey</a> - Your agent activation key. You can
--   get the activation key either by sending an HTTP GET request with
--   redirects that enable you to get the agent IP address (port 80).
--   Alternatively, you can get it from the DataSync console.
--   
--   The redirect URL returned in the response provides you the activation
--   key for your agent in the query string parameter
--   <tt>activationKey</tt>. It might also include other activation-related
--   parameters; however, these are merely defaults. The arguments you pass
--   to this API call determine the actual configuration of your agent.
--   
--   For more information, see Activating an Agent in the /DataSync User
--   Guide./
newCreateAgent :: Text -> CreateAgent

-- | The ARNs of the security groups used to protect your data transfer
--   task subnets. See <a>SecurityGroupArns</a>.
createAgent_securityGroupArns :: Lens' CreateAgent (Maybe (NonEmpty Text))

-- | The Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) of the subnets in which DataSync will
--   create elastic network interfaces for each data transfer task. The
--   agent that runs a task must be private. When you start a task that is
--   associated with an agent created in a VPC, or one that has access to
--   an IP address in a VPC, then the task is also private. In this case,
--   DataSync creates four network interfaces for each task in your subnet.
--   For a data transfer to work, the agent must be able to route to all
--   these four network interfaces.
createAgent_subnetArns :: Lens' CreateAgent (Maybe (NonEmpty Text))

-- | The name you configured for your agent. This value is a text reference
--   that is used to identify the agent in the console.
createAgent_agentName :: Lens' CreateAgent (Maybe Text)

-- | The ID of the VPC (virtual private cloud) endpoint that the agent has
--   access to. This is the client-side VPC endpoint, also called a
--   PrivateLink. If you don't have a PrivateLink VPC endpoint, see
--   <a>Creating a VPC Endpoint Service Configuration</a> in the Amazon VPC
--   User Guide.
--   
--   VPC endpoint ID looks like this: <tt>vpce-01234d5aff67890e1</tt>.
createAgent_vpcEndpointId :: Lens' CreateAgent (Maybe Text)

-- | The key-value pair that represents the tag that you want to associate
--   with the agent. The value can be an empty string. This value helps you
--   manage, filter, and search for your agents.
--   
--   Valid characters for key and value are letters, spaces, and numbers
--   representable in UTF-8 format, and the following special characters: +
--   - = . _ : / @.
createAgent_tags :: Lens' CreateAgent (Maybe [TagListEntry])

-- | Your agent activation key. You can get the activation key either by
--   sending an HTTP GET request with redirects that enable you to get the
--   agent IP address (port 80). Alternatively, you can get it from the
--   DataSync console.
--   
--   The redirect URL returned in the response provides you the activation
--   key for your agent in the query string parameter
--   <tt>activationKey</tt>. It might also include other activation-related
--   parameters; however, these are merely defaults. The arguments you pass
--   to this API call determine the actual configuration of your agent.
--   
--   For more information, see Activating an Agent in the /DataSync User
--   Guide./
createAgent_activationKey :: Lens' CreateAgent Text

-- | CreateAgentResponse
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateAgentResponse</a> smart constructor.
data CreateAgentResponse
CreateAgentResponse' :: Maybe Text -> Int -> CreateAgentResponse

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the agent. Use the
--   <tt>ListAgents</tt> operation to return a list of agents for your
--   account and Amazon Web Services Region.
[$sel:agentArn:CreateAgentResponse'] :: CreateAgentResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:CreateAgentResponse'] :: CreateAgentResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateAgentResponse</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentArn:CreateAgentResponse'</a>,
--   <a>createAgentResponse_agentArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
--   of the agent. Use the <tt>ListAgents</tt> operation to return a list
--   of agents for your account and Amazon Web Services Region.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:CreateAgentResponse'</a>,
--   <a>createAgentResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status
--   code.
newCreateAgentResponse :: Int -> CreateAgentResponse

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the agent. Use the
--   <tt>ListAgents</tt> operation to return a list of agents for your
--   account and Amazon Web Services Region.
createAgentResponse_agentArn :: Lens' CreateAgentResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | The response's http status code.
createAgentResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' CreateAgentResponse Int

instance Network.AWS.Data.Path.ToPath Network.AWS.DataSync.CreateAgent.CreateAgent
instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.DataSync.CreateAgent.CreateAgent


-- | Cancels execution of a task.
--   
--   When you cancel a task execution, the transfer of some files is
--   abruptly interrupted. The contents of files that are transferred to
--   the destination might be incomplete or inconsistent with the source
--   files. However, if you start a new task execution on the same task and
--   you allow the task execution to complete, file content on the
--   destination is complete and consistent. This applies to other
--   unexpected failures that interrupt a task execution. In all of these
--   cases, DataSync successfully complete the transfer when you start the
--   next task execution.
module Network.AWS.DataSync.CancelTaskExecution

-- | CancelTaskExecutionRequest
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCancelTaskExecution</a> smart constructor.
data CancelTaskExecution
CancelTaskExecution' :: Text -> CancelTaskExecution

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the task execution to cancel.
[$sel:taskExecutionArn:CancelTaskExecution'] :: CancelTaskExecution -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>CancelTaskExecution</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:taskExecutionArn:CancelTaskExecution'</a>,
--   <a>cancelTaskExecution_taskExecutionArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of the task execution to cancel.
newCancelTaskExecution :: Text -> CancelTaskExecution

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the task execution to cancel.
cancelTaskExecution_taskExecutionArn :: Lens' CancelTaskExecution Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCancelTaskExecutionResponse</a> smart constructor.
data CancelTaskExecutionResponse
CancelTaskExecutionResponse' :: Int -> CancelTaskExecutionResponse

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:CancelTaskExecutionResponse'] :: CancelTaskExecutionResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>CancelTaskExecutionResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:CancelTaskExecutionResponse'</a>,
--   <a>cancelTaskExecutionResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http
--   status code.
newCancelTaskExecutionResponse :: Int -> CancelTaskExecutionResponse

-- | The response's http status code.
cancelTaskExecutionResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' CancelTaskExecutionResponse Int

-- | Updates some of the parameters of a previously created location for
--   Network File System (NFS) access. For information about creating an
--   NFS location, see <a>Creating a location for NFS</a>.
module Network.AWS.DataSync.UpdateLocationNfs

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateLocationNfs</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateLocationNfs
UpdateLocationNfs' :: Maybe OnPremConfig -> Maybe Text -> Maybe NfsMountOptions -> Text -> UpdateLocationNfs
[$sel:onPremConfig:UpdateLocationNfs'] :: UpdateLocationNfs -> Maybe OnPremConfig

-- | The subdirectory in the NFS file system that is used to read data from
--   the NFS source location or write data to the NFS destination. The NFS
--   path should be a path that's exported by the NFS server, or a
--   subdirectory of that path. The path should be such that it can be
--   mounted by other NFS clients in your network.
--   
--   To see all the paths exported by your NFS server, run "<tt>showmount
--   -e nfs-server-name</tt>" from an NFS client that has access to your
--   server. You can specify any directory that appears in the results, and
--   any subdirectory of that directory. Ensure that the NFS export is
--   accessible without Kerberos authentication.
--   
--   To transfer all the data in the folder that you specified, DataSync
--   must have permissions to read all the data. To ensure this, either
--   configure the NFS export with <tt>no_root_squash</tt>, or ensure that
--   the files you want DataSync to access have permissions that allow read
--   access for all users. Doing either option enables the agent to read
--   the files. For the agent to access directories, you must additionally
--   enable all execute access.
--   
--   If you are copying data to or from your Snowcone device, see <a>NFS
--   Server on Snowcone</a> for more information.
--   
--   For information about NFS export configuration, see 18.7. The
--   /etc/exports Configuration File in the Red Hat Enterprise Linux
--   documentation.
[$sel:subdirectory:UpdateLocationNfs'] :: UpdateLocationNfs -> Maybe Text
[$sel:mountOptions:UpdateLocationNfs'] :: UpdateLocationNfs -> Maybe NfsMountOptions

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the NFS location to update.
[$sel:locationArn:UpdateLocationNfs'] :: UpdateLocationNfs -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateLocationNfs</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:onPremConfig:UpdateLocationNfs'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationNfs_onPremConfig</a> - Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subdirectory:UpdateLocationNfs'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationNfs_subdirectory</a> - The subdirectory in the NFS
--   file system that is used to read data from the NFS source location or
--   write data to the NFS destination. The NFS path should be a path
--   that's exported by the NFS server, or a subdirectory of that path. The
--   path should be such that it can be mounted by other NFS clients in
--   your network.
--   
--   To see all the paths exported by your NFS server, run "<tt>showmount
--   -e nfs-server-name</tt>" from an NFS client that has access to your
--   server. You can specify any directory that appears in the results, and
--   any subdirectory of that directory. Ensure that the NFS export is
--   accessible without Kerberos authentication.
--   
--   To transfer all the data in the folder that you specified, DataSync
--   must have permissions to read all the data. To ensure this, either
--   configure the NFS export with <tt>no_root_squash</tt>, or ensure that
--   the files you want DataSync to access have permissions that allow read
--   access for all users. Doing either option enables the agent to read
--   the files. For the agent to access directories, you must additionally
--   enable all execute access.
--   
--   If you are copying data to or from your Snowcone device, see <a>NFS
--   Server on Snowcone</a> for more information.
--   
--   For information about NFS export configuration, see 18.7. The
--   /etc/exports Configuration File in the Red Hat Enterprise Linux
--   documentation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:mountOptions:UpdateLocationNfs'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationNfs_mountOptions</a> - Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:locationArn:UpdateLocationNfs'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationNfs_locationArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
--   of the NFS location to update.
newUpdateLocationNfs :: Text -> UpdateLocationNfs

-- | Undocumented member.
updateLocationNfs_onPremConfig :: Lens' UpdateLocationNfs (Maybe OnPremConfig)

-- | The subdirectory in the NFS file system that is used to read data from
--   the NFS source location or write data to the NFS destination. The NFS
--   path should be a path that's exported by the NFS server, or a
--   subdirectory of that path. The path should be such that it can be
--   mounted by other NFS clients in your network.
--   
--   To see all the paths exported by your NFS server, run "<tt>showmount
--   -e nfs-server-name</tt>" from an NFS client that has access to your
--   server. You can specify any directory that appears in the results, and
--   any subdirectory of that directory. Ensure that the NFS export is
--   accessible without Kerberos authentication.
--   
--   To transfer all the data in the folder that you specified, DataSync
--   must have permissions to read all the data. To ensure this, either
--   configure the NFS export with <tt>no_root_squash</tt>, or ensure that
--   the files you want DataSync to access have permissions that allow read
--   access for all users. Doing either option enables the agent to read
--   the files. For the agent to access directories, you must additionally
--   enable all execute access.
--   
--   If you are copying data to or from your Snowcone device, see <a>NFS
--   Server on Snowcone</a> for more information.
--   
--   For information about NFS export configuration, see 18.7. The
--   /etc/exports Configuration File in the Red Hat Enterprise Linux
--   documentation.
updateLocationNfs_subdirectory :: Lens' UpdateLocationNfs (Maybe Text)

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateLocationNfsResponse</a> smart constructor.

-- | Updates some of the parameters of a previously created location for
--   self-managed object storage server access. For information about
--   creating a self-managed object storage location, see <a>Creating a
--   location for object storage</a>.
module Network.AWS.DataSync.UpdateLocationObjectStorage

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateLocationObjectStorage</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateLocationObjectStorage
UpdateLocationObjectStorage' :: Maybe Natural -> Maybe (NonEmpty Text) -> Maybe ObjectStorageServerProtocol -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Text -> UpdateLocationObjectStorage

-- | The port that your self-managed object storage server accepts inbound
--   network traffic on. The server port is set by default to TCP 80 (HTTP)
--   or TCP 443 (HTTPS). You can specify a custom port if your self-managed
--   object storage server requires one.
[$sel:serverPort:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'] :: UpdateLocationObjectStorage -> Maybe Natural

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the agents associated with the
--   self-managed object storage server location.
[$sel:agentArns:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'] :: UpdateLocationObjectStorage -> Maybe (NonEmpty Text)

-- | The protocol that the object storage server uses to communicate. Valid
--   values are <tt>HTTP</tt> or <tt>HTTPS</tt>.
[$sel:serverProtocol:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'] :: UpdateLocationObjectStorage -> Maybe ObjectStorageServerProtocol

-- | Optional. The secret key is used if credentials are required to access
--   the self-managed object storage server. If your object storage
--   requires a user name and password to authenticate, use
--   <tt>AccessKey</tt> and <tt>SecretKey</tt> to provide the user name and
--   password, respectively.
[$sel:secretKey:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'] :: UpdateLocationObjectStorage -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)

-- | The subdirectory in the self-managed object storage server that is
--   used to read data from.
[$sel:subdirectory:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'] :: UpdateLocationObjectStorage -> Maybe Text

-- | Optional. The access key is used if credentials are required to access
--   the self-managed object storage server. If your object storage
--   requires a user name and password to authenticate, use
--   <tt>AccessKey</tt> and <tt>SecretKey</tt> to provide the user name and
--   password, respectively.
[$sel:accessKey:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'] :: UpdateLocationObjectStorage -> Maybe Text

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the self-managed object storage
--   server location to be updated.
[$sel:locationArn:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'] :: UpdateLocationObjectStorage -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateLocationObjectStorage</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverPort:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationObjectStorage_serverPort</a> - The port that your
--   self-managed object storage server accepts inbound network traffic on.
--   The server port is set by default to TCP 80 (HTTP) or TCP 443 (HTTPS).
--   You can specify a custom port if your self-managed object storage
--   server requires one.
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentArns:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationObjectStorage_agentArns</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the agents associated with the self-managed object
--   storage server location.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverProtocol:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationObjectStorage_serverProtocol</a> - The protocol that
--   the object storage server uses to communicate. Valid values are
--   <tt>HTTP</tt> or <tt>HTTPS</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secretKey:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationObjectStorage_secretKey</a> - Optional. The secret
--   key is used if credentials are required to access the self-managed
--   object storage server. If your object storage requires a user name and
--   password to authenticate, use <tt>AccessKey</tt> and
--   <tt>SecretKey</tt> to provide the user name and password,
--   respectively.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subdirectory:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationObjectStorage_subdirectory</a> - The subdirectory in
--   the self-managed object storage server that is used to read data from.
--   
--   <a>$sel:accessKey:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationObjectStorage_accessKey</a> - Optional. The access
--   key is used if credentials are required to access the self-managed
--   object storage server. If your object storage requires a user name and
--   password to authenticate, use <tt>AccessKey</tt> and
--   <tt>SecretKey</tt> to provide the user name and password,
--   respectively.
--   
--   <a>$sel:locationArn:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationObjectStorage_locationArn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the self-managed object storage server location to be
--   updated.
newUpdateLocationObjectStorage :: Text -> UpdateLocationObjectStorage

-- | The port that your self-managed object storage server accepts inbound
--   network traffic on. The server port is set by default to TCP 80 (HTTP)
--   or TCP 443 (HTTPS). You can specify a custom port if your self-managed
--   object storage server requires one.
updateLocationObjectStorage_serverPort :: Lens' UpdateLocationObjectStorage (Maybe Natural)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the agents associated with the
--   self-managed object storage server location.
updateLocationObjectStorage_agentArns :: Lens' UpdateLocationObjectStorage (Maybe (NonEmpty Text))

-- | The protocol that the object storage server uses to communicate. Valid
--   values are <tt>HTTP</tt> or <tt>HTTPS</tt>.
updateLocationObjectStorage_serverProtocol :: Lens' UpdateLocationObjectStorage (Maybe ObjectStorageServerProtocol)

-- | Optional. The secret key is used if credentials are required to access
--   the self-managed object storage server. If your object storage
--   requires a user name and password to authenticate, use
--   <tt>AccessKey</tt> and <tt>SecretKey</tt> to provide the user name and
--   password, respectively.
updateLocationObjectStorage_secretKey :: Lens' UpdateLocationObjectStorage (Maybe Text)

-- | The subdirectory in the self-managed object storage server that is
--   used to read data from.
updateLocationObjectStorage_subdirectory :: Lens' UpdateLocationObjectStorage (Maybe Text)

-- | Optional. The access key is used if credentials are required to access
--   the self-managed object storage server. If your object storage
--   requires a user name and password to authenticate, use
--   <tt>AccessKey</tt> and <tt>SecretKey</tt> to provide the user name and
--   password, respectively.
updateLocationObjectStorage_accessKey :: Lens' UpdateLocationObjectStorage (Maybe Text)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the self-managed object storage
--   server location to be updated.
updateLocationObjectStorage_locationArn :: Lens' UpdateLocationObjectStorage Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateLocationObjectStorageResponse</a> smart
--   constructor.

-- | Updates some of the parameters of a previously created location for
--   Server Message Block (SMB) file system access. For information about
--   creating an SMB location, see <a>Creating a location for SMB</a>.
module Network.AWS.DataSync.UpdateLocationSmb

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateLocationSmb</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateLocationSmb
UpdateLocationSmb' :: Maybe (NonEmpty Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe SmbMountOptions -> Text -> UpdateLocationSmb

-- | The Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) of agents to use for a Simple Message
--   Block (SMB) location.
[$sel:agentArns:UpdateLocationSmb'] :: UpdateLocationSmb -> Maybe (NonEmpty Text)

-- | The name of the Windows domain that the SMB server belongs to.
[$sel:domain:UpdateLocationSmb'] :: UpdateLocationSmb -> Maybe Text

-- | The user who can mount the share has the permissions to access files
--   and folders in the SMB share.
[$sel:user:UpdateLocationSmb'] :: UpdateLocationSmb -> Maybe Text

-- | The password of the user who can mount the share has the permissions
--   to access files and folders in the SMB share.
[$sel:password:UpdateLocationSmb'] :: UpdateLocationSmb -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)

-- | The subdirectory in the SMB file system that is used to read data from
--   the SMB source location or write data to the SMB destination. The SMB
--   path should be a path that's exported by the SMB server, or a
--   subdirectory of that path. The path should be such that it can be
--   mounted by other SMB clients in your network.
--   
--   <tt>Subdirectory</tt> must be specified with forward slashes. For
--   example, <tt>/path/to/folder</tt>.
--   
--   To transfer all the data in the folder that you specified, DataSync
--   must have permissions to mount the SMB share and to access all the
--   data in that share. To ensure this, do either of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Ensure that the user/password specified belongs to the user who
--   can mount the share and who has the appropriate permissions for all of
--   the files and directories that you want DataSync to access.</li>
--   <li>Use credentials of a member of the Backup Operators group to mount
--   the share.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   Doing either of these options enables the agent to access the data.
--   For the agent to access directories, you must also enable all execute
--   access.
[$sel:subdirectory:UpdateLocationSmb'] :: UpdateLocationSmb -> Maybe Text
[$sel:mountOptions:UpdateLocationSmb'] :: UpdateLocationSmb -> Maybe SmbMountOptions

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the SMB location to update.
[$sel:locationArn:UpdateLocationSmb'] :: UpdateLocationSmb -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateLocationSmb</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentArns:UpdateLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationSmb_agentArns</a> - The Amazon Resource Names (ARNs)
--   of agents to use for a Simple Message Block (SMB) location.
--   
--   <a>$sel:domain:UpdateLocationSmb'</a>, <a>updateLocationSmb_domain</a>
--   - The name of the Windows domain that the SMB server belongs to.
--   
--   <a>$sel:user:UpdateLocationSmb'</a>, <a>updateLocationSmb_user</a> -
--   The user who can mount the share has the permissions to access files
--   and folders in the SMB share.
--   
--   <a>$sel:password:UpdateLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationSmb_password</a> - The password of the user who can
--   mount the share has the permissions to access files and folders in the
--   SMB share.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subdirectory:UpdateLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationSmb_subdirectory</a> - The subdirectory in the SMB
--   file system that is used to read data from the SMB source location or
--   write data to the SMB destination. The SMB path should be a path
--   that's exported by the SMB server, or a subdirectory of that path. The
--   path should be such that it can be mounted by other SMB clients in
--   your network.
--   
--   <tt>Subdirectory</tt> must be specified with forward slashes. For
--   example, <tt>/path/to/folder</tt>.
--   
--   To transfer all the data in the folder that you specified, DataSync
--   must have permissions to mount the SMB share and to access all the
--   data in that share. To ensure this, do either of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Ensure that the user/password specified belongs to the user who
--   can mount the share and who has the appropriate permissions for all of
--   the files and directories that you want DataSync to access.</li>
--   <li>Use credentials of a member of the Backup Operators group to mount
--   the share.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   Doing either of these options enables the agent to access the data.
--   For the agent to access directories, you must also enable all execute
--   access.
--   
--   <a>$sel:mountOptions:UpdateLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationSmb_mountOptions</a> - Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:locationArn:UpdateLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationSmb_locationArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
--   of the SMB location to update.
newUpdateLocationSmb :: Text -> UpdateLocationSmb

-- | The Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) of agents to use for a Simple Message
--   Block (SMB) location.
updateLocationSmb_agentArns :: Lens' UpdateLocationSmb (Maybe (NonEmpty Text))

-- | The name of the Windows domain that the SMB server belongs to.
updateLocationSmb_domain :: Lens' UpdateLocationSmb (Maybe Text)

-- | The user who can mount the share has the permissions to access files
--   and folders in the SMB share.
updateLocationSmb_user :: Lens' UpdateLocationSmb (Maybe Text)

-- | The password of the user who can mount the share has the permissions
--   to access files and folders in the SMB share.
updateLocationSmb_password :: Lens' UpdateLocationSmb (Maybe Text)

-- | The subdirectory in the SMB file system that is used to read data from
--   the SMB source location or write data to the SMB destination. The SMB
--   path should be a path that's exported by the SMB server, or a
--   subdirectory of that path. The path should be such that it can be
--   mounted by other SMB clients in your network.
--   
--   <tt>Subdirectory</tt> must be specified with forward slashes. For
--   example, <tt>/path/to/folder</tt>.
--   
--   To transfer all the data in the folder that you specified, DataSync
--   must have permissions to mount the SMB share and to access all the
--   data in that share. To ensure this, do either of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Ensure that the user/password specified belongs to the user who
--   can mount the share and who has the appropriate permissions for all of
--   the files and directories that you want DataSync to access.</li>
--   <li>Use credentials of a member of the Backup Operators group to mount
--   the share.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   Doing either of these options enables the agent to access the data.
--   For the agent to access directories, you must also enable all execute
--   access.
updateLocationSmb_subdirectory :: Lens' UpdateLocationSmb (Maybe Text)

-- | Undocumented member.
updateLocationSmb_mountOptions :: Lens' UpdateLocationSmb (Maybe SmbMountOptions)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the SMB location to update.
updateLocationSmb_locationArn :: Lens' UpdateLocationSmb Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateLocationSmbResponse</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateLocationSmbResponse
UpdateLocationSmbResponse' :: Int -> UpdateLocationSmbResponse

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:UpdateLocationSmbResponse'] :: UpdateLocationSmbResponse -> Int

--   fields omitted.

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

--   <a>updateLocationSmbResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http
--   status code.
newUpdateLocationSmbResponse :: Int -> UpdateLocationSmbResponse

updateLocationSmbResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' UpdateLocationSmbResponse Int

-- | Updates the metadata associated with a task.
module Network.AWS.DataSync.UpdateTask

-- | UpdateTaskResponse
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateTask</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateTask
UpdateTask' :: Maybe TaskSchedule -> Maybe [FilterRule] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [FilterRule] -> Maybe Options -> Maybe Text -> Text -> UpdateTask

-- | Specifies a schedule used to periodically transfer files from a source
--   to a destination location. You can configure your task to execute
--   hourly, daily, weekly or on specific days of the week. You control
--   when in the day or hour you want the task to execute. The time you
--   specify is UTC time. For more information, see <a>Scheduling your
--   task</a>.
[$sel:schedule:UpdateTask'] :: UpdateTask -> Maybe TaskSchedule

-- | A list of filter rules that determines which files to include when
--   running a task. The pattern should contain a single filter string that
--   consists of the patterns to include. The patterns are delimited by "|"
--   (that is, a pipe). For example: <tt>"/folder1|/folder2</tt>"
[$sel:includes:UpdateTask'] :: UpdateTask -> Maybe [FilterRule]

-- | The name of the task to update.
[$sel:name:UpdateTask'] :: UpdateTask -> Maybe Text

-- | A list of filter rules that determines which files to exclude from a
--   task. The list should contain a single filter string that consists of
--   the patterns to exclude. The patterns are delimited by "|" (that is, a
--   pipe), for example: <tt>"/folder1|/folder2"</tt>
[$sel:excludes:UpdateTask'] :: UpdateTask -> Maybe [FilterRule]
[$sel:options:UpdateTask'] :: UpdateTask -> Maybe Options

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource name of the CloudWatch
--   LogGroup.
[$sel:cloudWatchLogGroupArn:UpdateTask'] :: UpdateTask -> Maybe Text

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource name of the task to
--   update.
[$sel:taskArn:UpdateTask'] :: UpdateTask -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateTask</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:schedule:UpdateTask'</a>, <a>updateTask_schedule</a> -
--   Specifies a schedule used to periodically transfer files from a source
--   to a destination location. You can configure your task to execute
--   hourly, daily, weekly or on specific days of the week. You control
--   when in the day or hour you want the task to execute. The time you
--   specify is UTC time. For more information, see <a>Scheduling your
--   task</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:includes:UpdateTask'</a>, <a>updateTask_includes</a> - A list
--   of filter rules that determines which files to include when running a
--   task. The pattern should contain a single filter string that consists
--   of the patterns to include. The patterns are delimited by "|" (that
--   is, a pipe). For example: <tt>"/folder1|/folder2</tt>"
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:UpdateTask'</a>, <a>updateTask_name</a> - The name of the
--   task to update.
--   
--   <a>$sel:excludes:UpdateTask'</a>, <a>updateTask_excludes</a> - A list
--   of filter rules that determines which files to exclude from a task.
--   The list should contain a single filter string that consists of the
--   patterns to exclude. The patterns are delimited by "|" (that is, a
--   pipe), for example: <tt>"/folder1|/folder2"</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:options:UpdateTask'</a>, <a>updateTask_options</a> -
--   Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cloudWatchLogGroupArn:UpdateTask'</a>,
--   <a>updateTask_cloudWatchLogGroupArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of the resource name of the CloudWatch LogGroup.
--   
--   <a>$sel:taskArn:UpdateTask'</a>, <a>updateTask_taskArn</a> - The
--   Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource name of the task to update.
newUpdateTask :: Text -> UpdateTask

-- | Specifies a schedule used to periodically transfer files from a source
--   to a destination location. You can configure your task to execute
--   hourly, daily, weekly or on specific days of the week. You control
--   when in the day or hour you want the task to execute. The time you
--   specify is UTC time. For more information, see <a>Scheduling your
--   task</a>.
updateTask_schedule :: Lens' UpdateTask (Maybe TaskSchedule)

-- | A list of filter rules that determines which files to include when
--   running a task. The pattern should contain a single filter string that
--   consists of the patterns to include. The patterns are delimited by "|"
--   (that is, a pipe). For example: <tt>"/folder1|/folder2</tt>"
updateTask_includes :: Lens' UpdateTask (Maybe [FilterRule])

-- | The name of the task to update.
updateTask_name :: Lens' UpdateTask (Maybe Text)

-- | A list of filter rules that determines which files to exclude from a
--   task. The list should contain a single filter string that consists of
--   the patterns to exclude. The patterns are delimited by "|" (that is, a
--   pipe), for example: <tt>"/folder1|/folder2"</tt>
updateTask_excludes :: Lens' UpdateTask (Maybe [FilterRule])

-- | Undocumented member.
updateTask_options :: Lens' UpdateTask (Maybe Options)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource name of the CloudWatch
--   LogGroup.
updateTask_cloudWatchLogGroupArn :: Lens' UpdateTask (Maybe Text)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource name of the task to
--   update.
updateTask_taskArn :: Lens' UpdateTask Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateTaskResponse</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateTaskResponse
UpdateTaskResponse' :: Int -> UpdateTaskResponse

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:UpdateTaskResponse'] :: UpdateTaskResponse -> Int

--   omitted.

--   code.

-- | Updates execution of a task.
--   
--   You can modify bandwidth throttling for a task execution that is
--   running or queued. For more information, see <a>Adjusting Bandwidth
--   Throttling for a Task Execution</a>.
--   
--   The only <tt>Option</tt> that can be modified by
--   <tt>UpdateTaskExecution</tt> is <tt> BytesPerSecond </tt>.
module Network.AWS.DataSync.UpdateTaskExecution

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateTaskExecution</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateTaskExecution
UpdateTaskExecution' :: Text -> Options -> UpdateTaskExecution

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the specific task execution that is
--   being updated.
[$sel:taskExecutionArn:UpdateTaskExecution'] :: UpdateTaskExecution -> Text
[$sel:options:UpdateTaskExecution'] :: UpdateTaskExecution -> Options

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateTaskExecution</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:taskExecutionArn:UpdateTaskExecution'</a>,
--   <a>updateTaskExecution_taskExecutionArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of the specific task execution that is being updated.
--   
--   <a>$sel:options:UpdateTaskExecution'</a>,
--   <a>updateTaskExecution_options</a> - Undocumented member.
newUpdateTaskExecution :: Text -> Options -> UpdateTaskExecution

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the specific task execution that is
--   being updated.
updateTaskExecution_taskExecutionArn :: Lens' UpdateTaskExecution Text

-- | Undocumented member.
updateTaskExecution_options :: Lens' UpdateTaskExecution Options

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateTaskExecutionResponse</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateTaskExecutionResponse

[$sel:httpStatus:UpdateTaskExecutionResponse'] :: UpdateTaskExecutionResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateTaskExecutionResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:UpdateTaskExecutionResponse'</a>,
--   <a>updateTaskExecutionResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http
--   status code.
newUpdateTaskExecutionResponse :: Int -> UpdateTaskExecutionResponse
