-- | DescribeLocationSmbRequest
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newDescribeLocationSmb</a> smart constructor.
data DescribeLocationSmb
DescribeLocationSmb' :: Text -> DescribeLocationSmb

-- | Create a value of <a>DescribeLocationSmb</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:locationArn:DescribeLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>describeLocationSmb_locationArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of the SMB location to describe.
newDescribeLocationSmb :: Text -> DescribeLocationSmb

-- | DescribeLocationSmbResponse
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newDescribeLocationSmbResponse</a> smart constructor.
data DescribeLocationSmbResponse
DescribeLocationSmbResponse' :: Maybe POSIX -> Maybe (NonEmpty Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe SmbMountOptions -> Maybe Text -> Int -> DescribeLocationSmbResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>DescribeLocationSmbResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:creationTime:DescribeLocationSmbResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeLocationSmbResponse_creationTime</a> - The time that the
--   SMB location was created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentArns:DescribeLocationSmbResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeLocationSmbResponse_agentArns</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the source SMB file system location that is created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:domain:DescribeLocationSmbResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeLocationSmbResponse_domain</a> - The name of the Windows
--   domain that the SMB server belongs to.
--   
--   <a>$sel:locationUri:DescribeLocationSmbResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeLocationSmbResponse_locationUri</a> - The URL of the source
--   SMB location that was described.
--   
--   <a>$sel:user:DescribeLocationSmbResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeLocationSmbResponse_user</a> - The user who can mount the
--   share, has the permissions to access files and folders in the SMB
--   share.
--   
--   <a>$sel:mountOptions:DescribeLocationSmbResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeLocationSmbResponse_mountOptions</a> - The mount options
--   that are available for DataSync to use to access an SMB location.
--   
--   <a>$sel:locationArn:DescribeLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>describeLocationSmbResponse_locationArn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the SMB location that was described.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:DescribeLocationSmbResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeLocationSmbResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http
--   status code.
newDescribeLocationSmbResponse :: Int -> DescribeLocationSmbResponse

-- | CreateLocationNfsRequest
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateLocationNfs</a> smart constructor.
data CreateLocationNfs
CreateLocationNfs' :: Maybe NfsMountOptions -> Maybe [TagListEntry] -> Text -> Text -> OnPremConfig -> CreateLocationNfs

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateLocationNfs</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:mountOptions:CreateLocationNfs'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationNfs_mountOptions</a> - The NFS mount options that
--   DataSync can use to mount your NFS share.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateLocationNfs'</a>, <a>createLocationNfs_tags</a> -
--   The key-value pair that represents the tag that you want to add to the
--   location. The value can be an empty string. We recommend using tags to
--   name your resources.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subdirectory:CreateLocationNfs'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationNfs_subdirectory</a> - The subdirectory in the NFS
--   file system that is used to read data from the NFS source location or
--   write data to the NFS destination. The NFS path should be a path
--   that's exported by the NFS server, or a subdirectory of that path. The
--   path should be such that it can be mounted by other NFS clients in
--   your network.
--   
--   To see all the paths exported by your NFS server, run "<tt>showmount
--   -e nfs-server-name</tt>" from an NFS client that has access to your
--   server. You can specify any directory that appears in the results, and
--   any subdirectory of that directory. Ensure that the NFS export is
--   accessible without Kerberos authentication.
--   
--   To transfer all the data in the folder you specified, DataSync needs
--   to have permissions to read all the data. To ensure this, either
--   configure the NFS export with <tt>no_root_squash,</tt> or ensure that
--   the permissions for all of the files that you want DataSync allow read
--   access for all users. Doing either enables the agent to read the
--   files. For the agent to access directories, you must additionally
--   enable all execute access.
--   
--   If you are copying data to or from your Snowcone device, see <a>NFS
--   Server on Snowcone</a> for more information.
--   
--   For information about NFS export configuration, see 18.7. The
--   /etc/exports Configuration File in the Red Hat Enterprise Linux
--   documentation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverHostname:CreateLocationNfs'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationNfs_serverHostname</a> - The name of the NFS server.
--   This value is the IP address or Domain Name Service (DNS) name of the
--   NFS server. An agent that is installed on-premises uses this host name
--   to mount the NFS server in a network.
--   
--   If you are copying data to or from your Snowcone device, see <a>NFS
--   Server on Snowcone</a> for more information.
--   
--   This name must either be DNS-compliant or must be an IP version 4
--   (IPv4) address.
--   
--   <a>$sel:onPremConfig:CreateLocationNfs'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationNfs_onPremConfig</a> - Contains a list of Amazon
--   Resource Names (ARNs) of agents that are used to connect to an NFS
--   server.
--   
--   If you are copying data to or from your Snowcone device, see <a>NFS
--   Server on Snowcone</a> for more information.
newCreateLocationNfs :: Text -> Text -> OnPremConfig -> CreateLocationNfs

data DescribeTaskResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>DescribeTaskResponse</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:creationTime:DescribeTaskResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskResponse_creationTime</a> - The time that the task was
--   created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:DescribeTaskResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskResponse_status</a> - The status of the task that was
--   described.
--   
--   For detailed information about task execution statuses, see
--   Understanding Task Statuses in the <i>DataSync User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:schedule:DescribeTaskResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskResponse_schedule</a> - The schedule used to
--   periodically transfer files from a source to a destination location.
--   
--   <a>$sel:taskArn:DescribeTask'</a>, <a>describeTaskResponse_taskArn</a>
--   - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the task that was described.
--   
--   <a>$sel:currentTaskExecutionArn:DescribeTaskResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskResponse_currentTaskExecutionArn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the task execution that is syncing files.
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationNetworkInterfaceArns:DescribeTaskResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskResponse_destinationNetworkInterfaceArns</a> - The
--   Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the destination ENIs (Elastic Network
--   Interface) that was created for your subnet.
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationLocationArn:DescribeTaskResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskResponse_destinationLocationArn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon Web Services storage resource's
--   location.
--   
--   <a>$sel:includes:DescribeTaskResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskResponse_includes</a> - A list of filter rules that
--   determines which files to include when running a task. The pattern
--   should contain a single filter string that consists of the patterns to
--   include. The patterns are delimited by "|" (that is, a pipe). For
--   example: <tt>"/folder1|/folder2</tt>"
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:DescribeTaskResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskResponse_name</a> - The name of the task that was
--   described.
--   
--   <a>$sel:errorCode:DescribeTaskResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskResponse_errorCode</a> - Errors that DataSync
--   encountered during execution of the task. You can use this error code
--   to help troubleshoot issues.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourceLocationArn:DescribeTaskResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskResponse_sourceLocationArn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the source file system's location.
--   
--   <a>$sel:excludes:DescribeTaskResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskResponse_excludes</a> - A list of filter rules that
--   determines which files to exclude from a task. The list should contain
--   a single filter string that consists of the patterns to exclude. The
--   patterns are delimited by "|" (that is, a pipe), for example:
--   <tt>"/folder1|/folder2"</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourceNetworkInterfaceArns:DescribeTaskResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskResponse_sourceNetworkInterfaceArns</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the source ENIs (Elastic Network Interface)
--   that was created for your subnet.
--   
--   <a>$sel:options:DescribeTaskResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskResponse_options</a> - The set of configuration options
--   that control the behavior of a single execution of the task that
--   occurs when you call <tt>StartTaskExecution</tt>. You can configure
--   these options to preserve metadata such as user ID (UID) and group
--   (GID), file permissions, data integrity verification, and so on.
--   
--   For each individual task execution, you can override these options by
--   specifying the overriding <tt>OverrideOptions</tt> value to
--   <a>StartTaskExecution</a> operation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cloudWatchLogGroupArn:DescribeTaskResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskResponse_cloudWatchLogGroupArn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon CloudWatch log group that was used
--   to monitor and log events in the task.
--   
--   For more information on these groups, see Working with Log Groups and
--   Log Streams in the <i>Amazon CloudWatch User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:errorDetail:DescribeTaskResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskResponse_errorDetail</a> - Detailed description of an
--   error that was encountered during the task execution. You can use this
--   information to help troubleshoot issues.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:DescribeTaskResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status
--   code.
newDescribeTaskResponse :: Int -> DescribeTaskResponse

data DescribeLocationS3Response
DescribeLocationS3Response' :: Maybe POSIX -> Maybe (NonEmpty Text) -> Maybe S3StorageClass -> Maybe Text -> Maybe S3Config -> Maybe Text -> Int -> DescribeLocationS3Response

-- | Create a value of <a>DescribeLocationS3Response</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:creationTime:DescribeLocationS3Response'</a>,
--   <a>describeLocationS3Response_creationTime</a> - The time that the
--   Amazon S3 bucket location was created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentArns:DescribeLocationS3Response'</a>,
--   <a>describeLocationS3Response_agentArns</a> - If you are using
--   DataSync on an Amazon Web Services Outpost, the Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARNs) of the EC2 agents deployed on your Outpost. For more
--   information about launching a DataSync agent on an Amazon Web Services
--   Outpost, see <a>Deploy your DataSync agent on Outposts</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:s3StorageClass:DescribeLocationS3Response'</a>,
--   <a>describeLocationS3Response_s3StorageClass</a> - The Amazon S3
--   storage class that you chose to store your files in when this location
--   is used as a task destination. For more information about S3 storage
--   classes, see <a>Amazon S3 Storage Classes</a>. Some storage classes
--   have behaviors that can affect your S3 storage cost. For detailed
--   information, see <a>Considerations when working with S3 storage
--   classes in DataSync</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:locationUri:DescribeLocationS3Response'</a>,
--   <a>describeLocationS3Response_locationUri</a> - The URL of the Amazon
--   S3 location that was described.
--   
--   <a>$sel:s3Config:DescribeLocationS3Response'</a>,
--   <a>describeLocationS3Response_s3Config</a> - Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:locationArn:DescribeLocationS3'</a>,
--   <a>describeLocationS3Response_locationArn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the Amazon S3 bucket or access point.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:DescribeLocationS3Response'</a>,
--   <a>describeLocationS3Response_httpStatus</a> - The response's http
--   status code.

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateLocationSmb</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateLocationSmb
UpdateLocationSmb' :: Maybe (NonEmpty Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe SmbMountOptions -> Text -> UpdateLocationSmb

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateLocationSmb</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentArns:UpdateLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationSmb_agentArns</a> - The Amazon Resource Names (ARNs)
--   of agents to use for a Simple Message Block (SMB) location.
--   
--   <a>$sel:domain:UpdateLocationSmb'</a>, <a>updateLocationSmb_domain</a>
--   - The name of the Windows domain that the SMB server belongs to.
--   
--   <a>$sel:user:UpdateLocationSmb'</a>, <a>updateLocationSmb_user</a> -
--   The user who can mount the share has the permissions to access files
--   and folders in the SMB share.
--   
--   <a>$sel:password:UpdateLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationSmb_password</a> - The password of the user who can
--   mount the share has the permissions to access files and folders in the
--   SMB share.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subdirectory:UpdateLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationSmb_subdirectory</a> - The subdirectory in the SMB
--   file system that is used to read data from the SMB source location or
--   write data to the SMB destination. The SMB path should be a path
--   that's exported by the SMB server, or a subdirectory of that path. The
--   path should be such that it can be mounted by other SMB clients in
--   your network.
--   
--   <tt>Subdirectory</tt> must be specified with forward slashes. For
--   example, <tt>/path/to/folder</tt>.
--   
--   To transfer all the data in the folder that you specified, DataSync
--   must have permissions to mount the SMB share and to access all the
--   data in that share. To ensure this, do either of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Ensure that the user/password specified belongs to the user who
--   can mount the share and who has the appropriate permissions for all of
--   the files and directories that you want DataSync to access.</li>
--   <li>Use credentials of a member of the Backup Operators group to mount
--   the share.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   Doing either of these options enables the agent to access the data.
--   For the agent to access directories, you must also enable all execute
--   access.
--   
--   <a>$sel:mountOptions:UpdateLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationSmb_mountOptions</a> - Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:locationArn:UpdateLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationSmb_locationArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
--   of the SMB location to update.
newUpdateLocationSmb :: Text -> UpdateLocationSmb

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateLocationSmbResponse</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateLocationSmbResponse

--   task destination. For buckets in Amazon Web Services Regions, the
--   storage class defaults to Standard. For buckets on Outposts, the
--   storage class defaults to Amazon Web Services S3 Outposts.

data CreateTask
CreateTask' :: Maybe TaskSchedule -> Maybe [FilterRule] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [FilterRule] -> Maybe Options -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [TagListEntry] -> Text -> Text -> CreateTask

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateTask</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:schedule:CreateTask'</a>, <a>createTask_schedule</a> -
--   Specifies a schedule used to periodically transfer files from a source
--   to a destination location. The schedule should be specified in UTC
--   time. For more information, see <a>Scheduling your task</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:includes:CreateTask'</a>, <a>createTask_includes</a> - A list
--   of filter rules that determines which files to include when running a
--   task. The pattern should contain a single filter string that consists
--   of the patterns to include. The patterns are delimited by "|" (that
--   is, a pipe). For example: <tt>"/folder1|/folder2</tt>"
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:CreateTask'</a>, <a>createTask_name</a> - The name of a
--   task. This value is a text reference that is used to identify the task
--   in the console.
--   
--   <a>$sel:excludes:CreateTask'</a>, <a>createTask_excludes</a> - A list
--   of filter rules that determines which files to exclude from a task.
--   The list should contain a single filter string that consists of the
--   patterns to exclude. The patterns are delimited by "|" (that is, a
--   pipe), for example, <tt>"/folder1|/folder2"</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:options:CreateTask'</a>, <a>createTask_options</a> - The set
--   of configuration options that control the behavior of a single
--   execution of the task that occurs when you call
--   <tt>StartTaskExecution</tt>. You can configure these options to
--   preserve metadata such as user ID (UID) and group ID (GID), file
--   permissions, data integrity verification, and so on.
--   
--   For each individual task execution, you can override these options by
--   specifying the <tt>OverrideOptions</tt> before starting the task
--   execution. For more information, see the <a>StartTaskExecution</a>
--   operation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cloudWatchLogGroupArn:CreateTask'</a>,
--   <a>createTask_cloudWatchLogGroupArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of the Amazon CloudWatch log group that is used to monitor and
--   log events in the task.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateTask'</a>, <a>createTask_tags</a> - The key-value
--   pair that represents the tag that you want to add to the resource. The
--   value can be an empty string.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourceLocationArn:CreateTask'</a>,
--   <a>createTask_sourceLocationArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
--   of the source location for the task.
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationLocationArn:CreateTask'</a>,
--   <a>createTask_destinationLocationArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of an Amazon Web Services storage resource's location.
newCreateTask :: Text -> Text -> CreateTask

-- | CreateLocationEfsRequest
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateLocationEfs</a> smart constructor.
data CreateLocationEfs
CreateLocationEfs' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe [TagListEntry] -> Text -> Ec2Config -> CreateLocationEfs

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateLocationEfs</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:subdirectory:CreateLocationEfs'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationEfs_subdirectory</a> - A subdirectory in the
--   location’s path. This subdirectory in the EFS file system is used to
--   read data from the EFS source location or write data to the EFS
--   destination. By default, DataSync uses the root directory.
--   
--   <tt>Subdirectory</tt> must be specified with forward slashes. For
--   example, <tt>/path/to/folder</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateLocationEfs'</a>, <a>createLocationEfs_tags</a> -
--   The key-value pair that represents a tag that you want to add to the
--   resource. The value can be an empty string. This value helps you
--   manage, filter, and search for your resources. We recommend that you
--   create a name tag for your location.
--   
--   <a>$sel:efsFilesystemArn:CreateLocationEfs'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationEfs_efsFilesystemArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) for the Amazon EFS file system.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ec2Config:CreateLocationEfs'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationEfs_ec2Config</a> - The subnet and security group
--   that the Amazon EFS file system uses. The security group that you
--   provide needs to be able to communicate with the security group on the
--   mount target in the subnet specified.
--   
--   The exact relationship between security group M (of the mount target)
--   and security group S (which you provide for DataSync to use at this
--   stage) is as follows:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Security group M (which you associate with the mount target) must
--   allow inbound access for the Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) on
--   the NFS port (2049) from security group S. You can enable inbound
--   connections either by IP address (CIDR range) or security group.</li>
--   <li>Security group S (provided to DataSync to access EFS) should have
--   a rule that enables outbound connections to the NFS port on one of the
--   file system’s mount targets. You can enable outbound connections
--   either by IP address (CIDR range) or security group.For information
--   about security groups and mount targets, see Security Groups for
--   Amazon EC2 Instances and Mount Targets in the <i>Amazon EFS User
--   Guide.</i></li>
--   </ul>
newCreateLocationEfs :: Text -> Ec2Config -> CreateLocationEfs

--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateLocationEfsResponse</a> smart constructor.
data CreateLocationEfsResponse

data UpdateLocationNfs
UpdateLocationNfs' :: Maybe OnPremConfig -> Maybe Text -> Maybe NfsMountOptions -> Text -> UpdateLocationNfs

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateLocationNfs</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:onPremConfig:UpdateLocationNfs'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationNfs_onPremConfig</a> - Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subdirectory:UpdateLocationNfs'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationNfs_subdirectory</a> - The subdirectory in the NFS
--   file system that is used to read data from the NFS source location or
--   write data to the NFS destination. The NFS path should be a path
--   that's exported by the NFS server, or a subdirectory of that path. The
--   path should be such that it can be mounted by other NFS clients in
--   your network.
--   
--   To see all the paths exported by your NFS server, run "<tt>showmount
--   -e nfs-server-name</tt>" from an NFS client that has access to your
--   server. You can specify any directory that appears in the results, and
--   any subdirectory of that directory. Ensure that the NFS export is
--   accessible without Kerberos authentication.
--   
--   To transfer all the data in the folder that you specified, DataSync
--   must have permissions to read all the data. To ensure this, either
--   configure the NFS export with <tt>no_root_squash</tt>, or ensure that
--   the files you want DataSync to access have permissions that allow read
--   access for all users. Doing either option enables the agent to read
--   the files. For the agent to access directories, you must additionally
--   enable all execute access.
--   
--   If you are copying data to or from your Snowcone device, see <a>NFS
--   Server on Snowcone</a> for more information.
--   
--   For information about NFS export configuration, see 18.7. The
--   /etc/exports Configuration File in the Red Hat Enterprise Linux
--   documentation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:mountOptions:UpdateLocationNfs'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationNfs_mountOptions</a> - Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:locationArn:UpdateLocationNfs'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationNfs_locationArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
--   of the NFS location to update.
newUpdateLocationNfs :: Text -> UpdateLocationNfs

data DescribeTaskExecutionResponse
DescribeTaskExecutionResponse' :: Maybe TaskExecutionStatus -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Integer -> Maybe Integer -> Maybe Integer -> Maybe TaskExecutionResultDetail -> Maybe [FilterRule] -> Maybe Integer -> Maybe [FilterRule] -> Maybe Options -> Maybe Integer -> Int -> DescribeTaskExecutionResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>DescribeTaskExecutionResponse</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:DescribeTaskExecutionResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskExecutionResponse_status</a> - The status of the task
--   execution.
--   
--   For detailed information about task execution statuses, see
--   Understanding Task Statuses in the <i>DataSync User Guide.</i>
--   
--   <a>$sel:taskExecutionArn:DescribeTaskExecution'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskExecutionResponse_taskExecutionArn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the task execution that was described.
--   <tt>TaskExecutionArn</tt> is hierarchical and includes
--   <tt>TaskArn</tt> for the task that was executed.
--   
--   For example, a <tt>TaskExecution</tt> value with the ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:datasync:us-east-1:111222333444:task/task-0208075f79cedf4a2/execution/exec-08ef1e88ec491019b</tt>
--   executed the task with the ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:datasync:us-east-1:111222333444:task/task-0208075f79cedf4a2</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:startTime:DescribeTaskExecutionResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskExecutionResponse_startTime</a> - The time that the
--   task execution was started.
--   
--   <a>$sel:filesTransferred:DescribeTaskExecutionResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskExecutionResponse_filesTransferred</a> - The actual
--   number of files that was transferred over the network. This value is
--   calculated and updated on an ongoing basis during the TRANSFERRING
--   phase. It's updated periodically when each file is read from the
--   source and sent over the network.
--   
--   If failures occur during a transfer, this value can be less than
--   <tt>EstimatedFilesToTransfer</tt>. This value can also be greater than
--   <tt>EstimatedFilesTransferred</tt> in some cases. This element is
--   implementation-specific for some location types, so don't use it as an
--   indicator for a correct file number or to monitor your task execution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bytesWritten:DescribeTaskExecutionResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskExecutionResponse_bytesWritten</a> - The number of
--   logical bytes written to the destination Amazon Web Services storage
--   resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bytesTransferred:DescribeTaskExecutionResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskExecutionResponse_bytesTransferred</a> - The physical
--   number of bytes transferred over the network.
--   
--   <a>$sel:result:DescribeTaskExecutionResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskExecutionResponse_result</a> - The result of the task
--   execution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:includes:DescribeTaskExecutionResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskExecutionResponse_includes</a> - A list of filter rules
--   that determines which files to include when running a task. The list
--   should contain a single filter string that consists of the patterns to
--   include. The patterns are delimited by "|" (that is, a pipe), for
--   example: <tt>"/folder1|/folder2"</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:estimatedFilesToTransfer:DescribeTaskExecutionResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskExecutionResponse_estimatedFilesToTransfer</a> - The
--   expected number of files that is to be transferred over the network.
--   This value is calculated during the PREPARING phase, before the
--   TRANSFERRING phase. This value is the expected number of files to be
--   transferred. It's calculated based on comparing the content of the
--   source and destination locations and finding the delta that needs to
--   be transferred.
--   
--   <a>$sel:excludes:DescribeTaskExecutionResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskExecutionResponse_excludes</a> - A list of filter rules
--   that determines which files to exclude from a task. The list should
--   contain a single filter string that consists of the patterns to
--   exclude. The patterns are delimited by "|" (that is, a pipe), for
--   example: <tt>"/folder1|/folder2"</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:options:DescribeTaskExecutionResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskExecutionResponse_options</a> - Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:estimatedBytesToTransfer:DescribeTaskExecutionResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskExecutionResponse_estimatedBytesToTransfer</a> - The
--   estimated physical number of bytes that is to be transferred over the
--   network.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:DescribeTaskExecutionResponse'</a>,
--   <a>describeTaskExecutionResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http
--   status code.
newDescribeTaskExecutionResponse :: Int -> DescribeTaskExecutionResponse

-- | CreateLocationSmbRequest
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateLocationSmb</a> smart constructor.
data CreateLocationSmb
CreateLocationSmb' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe SmbMountOptions -> Maybe [TagListEntry] -> Text -> Text -> Text -> Sensitive Text -> NonEmpty Text -> CreateLocationSmb

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateLocationSmb</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:domain:CreateLocationSmb'</a>, <a>createLocationSmb_domain</a>
--   - The name of the Windows domain that the SMB server belongs to.
--   
--   <a>$sel:mountOptions:CreateLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationSmb_mountOptions</a> - The mount options used by
--   DataSync to access the SMB server.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateLocationSmb'</a>, <a>createLocationSmb_tags</a> -
--   The key-value pair that represents the tag that you want to add to the
--   location. The value can be an empty string. We recommend using tags to
--   name your resources.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subdirectory:CreateLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationSmb_subdirectory</a> - The subdirectory in the SMB
--   file system that is used to read data from the SMB source location or
--   write data to the SMB destination. The SMB path should be a path
--   that's exported by the SMB server, or a subdirectory of that path. The
--   path should be such that it can be mounted by other SMB clients in
--   your network.
--   
--   <tt>Subdirectory</tt> must be specified with forward slashes. For
--   example, <tt>/path/to/folder</tt>.
--   
--   To transfer all the data in the folder you specified, DataSync needs
--   to have permissions to mount the SMB share, as well as to access all
--   the data in that share. To ensure this, either ensure that the
--   user/password specified belongs to the user who can mount the share,
--   and who has the appropriate permissions for all of the files and
--   directories that you want DataSync to access, or use credentials of a
--   member of the Backup Operators group to mount the share. Doing either
--   enables the agent to access the data. For the agent to access
--   directories, you must additionally enable all execute access.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverHostname:CreateLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationSmb_serverHostname</a> - The name of the SMB server.
--   This value is the IP address or Domain Name Service (DNS) name of the
--   SMB server. An agent that is installed on-premises uses this hostname
--   to mount the SMB server in a network.
--   
--   This name must either be DNS-compliant or must be an IP version 4
--   (IPv4) address.
--   
--   <a>$sel:user:CreateLocationSmb'</a>, <a>createLocationSmb_user</a> -
--   The user who can mount the share, has the permissions to access files
--   and folders in the SMB share.
--   
--   For information about choosing a user name that ensures sufficient
--   permissions to files, folders, and metadata, see <a>user</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:password:CreateLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationSmb_password</a> - The password of the user who can
--   mount the share, has the permissions to access files and folders in
--   the SMB share.
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentArns:CreateLocationSmb'</a>,
--   <a>createLocationSmb_agentArns</a> - The Amazon Resource Names (ARNs)
--   of agents to use for a Simple Message Block (SMB) location.
newCreateLocationSmb :: Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> NonEmpty Text -> CreateLocationSmb

--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateLocationSmbResponse</a> smart constructor.

-- | CreateAgentRequest

--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateAgent</a> smart constructor.
data CreateAgent
CreateAgent' :: Maybe (NonEmpty Text) -> Maybe (NonEmpty Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [TagListEntry] -> Text -> CreateAgent

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateAgent</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:securityGroupArns:CreateAgent'</a>,
--   <a>createAgent_securityGroupArns</a> - The ARNs of the security groups
--   used to protect your data transfer task subnets. See
--   <a>SecurityGroupArns</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subnetArns:CreateAgent'</a>, <a>createAgent_subnetArns</a> -
--   The Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) of the subnets in which DataSync will
--   create elastic network interfaces for each data transfer task. The
--   agent that runs a task must be private. When you start a task that is
--   associated with an agent created in a VPC, or one that has access to
--   an IP address in a VPC, then the task is also private. In this case,
--   DataSync creates four network interfaces for each task in your subnet.
--   For a data transfer to work, the agent must be able to route to all
--   these four network interfaces.
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentName:CreateAgent'</a>, <a>createAgent_agentName</a> - The
--   name you configured for your agent. This value is a text reference
--   that is used to identify the agent in the console.
--   
--   <a>$sel:vpcEndpointId:CreateAgent'</a>,
--   <a>createAgent_vpcEndpointId</a> - The ID of the VPC (virtual private
--   cloud) endpoint that the agent has access to. This is the client-side
--   VPC endpoint, also called a PrivateLink. If you don't have a
--   PrivateLink VPC endpoint, see <a>Creating a VPC Endpoint Service
--   Configuration</a> in the Amazon VPC User Guide.
--   
--   VPC endpoint ID looks like this: <tt>vpce-01234d5aff67890e1</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateAgent'</a>, <a>createAgent_tags</a> - The key-value
--   pair that represents the tag that you want to associate with the
--   agent. The value can be an empty string. This value helps you manage,
--   filter, and search for your agents.
--   
--   Valid characters for key and value are letters, spaces, and numbers
--   representable in UTF-8 format, and the following special characters: +
--   - = . _ : / @.
--   
--   <a>$sel:activationKey:CreateAgent'</a>,
--   <a>createAgent_activationKey</a> - Your agent activation key. You can
--   get the activation key either by sending an HTTP GET request with
--   redirects that enable you to get the agent IP address (port 80).
--   Alternatively, you can get it from the DataSync console.
--   
--   The redirect URL returned in the response provides you the activation
--   key for your agent in the query string parameter
--   <tt>activationKey</tt>. It might also include other activation-related
--   parameters; however, these are merely defaults. The arguments you pass
--   to this API call determine the actual configuration of your agent.
--   
--   For more information, see Activating an Agent in the /DataSync User
--   Guide./
newCreateAgent :: Text -> CreateAgent

-- | CreateAgentResponse
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateAgentResponse</a> smart constructor.

CreateAgentResponse' :: Maybe Text -> Int -> CreateAgentResponse

--   omitted.

--   fields.

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

--   <a>$sel:agentArn:CreateAgentResponse'</a>,

--   of the agent. Use the <tt>ListAgents</tt> operation to return a list
--   of agents for your account and Amazon Web Services Region.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:CreateAgentResponse'</a>,
--   <a>createAgentResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status
--   code.

--   The server port is set by default to TCP 80 (HTTP) or TCP 443 (HTTPS).
--   You can specify a custom port if your self-managed object storage
--   server requires one.
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentArns:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationObjectStorage_agentArns</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the agents associated with the self-managed object
--   storage server location.

--   the object storage server uses to communicate. Valid values are
--   <tt>HTTP</tt> or <tt>HTTPS</tt>.

--   <a>updateLocationObjectStorage_secretKey</a> - Optional. The secret
--   key is used if credentials are required to access the self-managed
--   object storage server. If your object storage requires a user name and
--   password to authenticate, use <tt>AccessKey</tt> and
--   <tt>SecretKey</tt> to provide the user name and password,
--   respectively.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subdirectory:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationObjectStorage_subdirectory</a> - The subdirectory in
--   the self-managed object storage server that is used to read data from.
--   
--   <a>$sel:accessKey:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationObjectStorage_accessKey</a> - Optional. The access
--   key is used if credentials are required to access the self-managed
--   object storage server. If your object storage requires a user name and
--   password to authenticate, use <tt>AccessKey</tt> and
--   <tt>SecretKey</tt> to provide the user name and password,
--   respectively.
--   
--   <a>$sel:locationArn:UpdateLocationObjectStorage'</a>,
--   <a>updateLocationObjectStorage_locationArn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the self-managed object storage server location to be

-- | The subnet and the security group that DataSync uses to access target
--   EFS file system. The subnet must have at least one mount target for
--   that file system. The security group that you provide needs to be able
--   to communicate with the security group on the mount target in the
--   subnet specified.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newEc2Config</a> smart constructor.
data Ec2Config
Ec2Config' :: Text -> NonEmpty Text -> Ec2Config

-- | Create a value of <a>Ec2Config</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:subnetArn:Ec2Config'</a>, <a>ec2Config_subnetArn</a> - The ARN
--   of the subnet and the security group that DataSync uses to access the
--   target EFS file system.
--   
--   <a>$sel:securityGroupArns:Ec2Config'</a>,
--   <a>ec2Config_securityGroupArns</a> - The Amazon Resource Names (ARNs)
--   of the security groups that are configured for the Amazon EC2
--   resource.
newEc2Config :: Text -> NonEmpty Text -> Ec2Config

-- | Specifies which files, folders, and objects to include or exclude when
--   transferring files from source to destination.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newFilterRule</a> smart constructor.
data FilterRule
FilterRule' :: Maybe FilterType -> Maybe Text -> FilterRule

-- | Create a value of <a>FilterRule</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:filterType:FilterRule'</a>, <a>filterRule_filterType</a> - The
--   type of filter rule to apply. DataSync only supports the
--   SIMPLE_PATTERN rule type.
--   
--   <a>$sel:value:FilterRule'</a>, <a>filterRule_value</a> - A single
--   filter string that consists of the patterns to include or exclude. The
--   patterns are delimited by "|" (that is, a pipe), for example:
--   <tt>/folder1|/folder2</tt>
newFilterRule :: FilterRule

-- | You can use API filters to narrow down the list of resources returned
--   by <tt>ListLocations</tt>. For example, to retrieve all your Amazon S3
--   locations, you can use <tt>ListLocations</tt> with filter name
--   <tt>LocationType S3</tt> and <tt>Operator Equals</tt>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newLocationFilter</a> smart constructor.
data LocationFilter
LocationFilter' :: LocationFilterName -> [Text] -> Operator -> LocationFilter

-- | Create a value of <a>LocationFilter</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:LocationFilter'</a>, <a>locationFilter_name</a> - The
--   name of the filter being used. Each API call supports a list of
--   filters that are available for it (for example, <tt>LocationType</tt>
--   for <tt>ListLocations</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:values:LocationFilter'</a>, <a>locationFilter_values</a> - The
--   values that you want to filter for. For example, you might want to
--   display only Amazon S3 locations.
--   
--   <a>$sel:operator:LocationFilter'</a>, <a>locationFilter_operator</a> -
--   The operator that is used to compare filter values (for example,
--   <tt>Equals</tt> or <tt>Contains</tt>). For more about API filtering
--   operators, see <a>API filters for ListTasks and ListLocations</a>.
newLocationFilter :: LocationFilterName -> Operator -> LocationFilter

-- | Represents a single entry in a list of locations.
--   <tt>LocationListEntry</tt> returns an array that contains a list of
--   locations when the <a>ListLocations</a> operation is called.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newLocationListEntry</a> smart constructor.
data LocationListEntry
LocationListEntry' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> LocationListEntry

-- | Create a value of <a>LocationListEntry</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:locationUri:LocationListEntry'</a>,
--   <a>locationListEntry_locationUri</a> - Represents a list of URLs of a
--   location. <tt>LocationUri</tt> returns an array that contains a list
--   of locations when the <a>ListLocations</a> operation is called.
--   
--   Format: <tt>TYPE://GLOBAL_ID/SUBDIR</tt>.
--   
--   TYPE designates the type of location. Valid values: NFS | EFS | S3.
--   
--   GLOBAL_ID is the globally unique identifier of the resource that backs
--   the location. An example for EFS is <tt>us-east-2.fs-abcd1234</tt>. An
--   example for Amazon S3 is the bucket name, such as <tt>myBucket</tt>.
--   An example for NFS is a valid IPv4 address or a host name compliant
--   with Domain Name Service (DNS).
--   
--   SUBDIR is a valid file system path, delimited by forward slashes as is
--   the *nix convention. For NFS and Amazon EFS, it's the export path to
--   mount the location. For Amazon S3, it's the prefix path that you mount
--   to and treat as the root of the location.
--   
--   <a>$sel:locationArn:LocationListEntry'</a>,
--   <a>locationListEntry_locationArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
--   of the location. For Network File System (NFS) or Amazon EFS, the
--   location is the export path. For Amazon S3, the location is the prefix
--   path that you want to mount and use as the root of the location.
newLocationListEntry :: LocationListEntry

-- | Represents the mount options that are available for DataSync to access
--   an NFS location.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newNfsMountOptions</a> smart constructor.
data NfsMountOptions
NfsMountOptions' :: Maybe NfsVersion -> NfsMountOptions

-- | Create a value of <a>NfsMountOptions</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:version:NfsMountOptions'</a>, <a>nfsMountOptions_version</a> -
--   The specific NFS version that you want DataSync to use to mount your
--   NFS share. If the server refuses to use the version specified, the
--   sync will fail. If you don't specify a version, DataSync defaults to
--   <tt>AUTOMATIC</tt>. That is, DataSync automatically selects a version
--   based on negotiation with the NFS server.
--   
--   You can specify the following NFS versions:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><a>NFSv3</a></b> - stateless protocol version that allows for
--   asynchronous writes on the server.</li>
--   <li><b><a>NFSv4.0</a></b> - stateful, firewall-friendly protocol
--   version that supports delegations and pseudo filesystems.</li>
--   <li><b><a>NFSv4.1</a></b> - stateful protocol version that supports
--   sessions, directory delegations, and parallel data processing. Version
--   4.1 also includes all features available in version 4.0.</li>
--   </ul>
newNfsMountOptions :: NfsMountOptions

-- | A list of Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) of agents to use for a Network
--   File System (NFS) location.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newOnPremConfig</a> smart constructor.
data OnPremConfig
OnPremConfig' :: NonEmpty Text -> OnPremConfig

-- | Create a value of <a>OnPremConfig</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:agentArns:OnPremConfig'</a>, <a>onPremConfig_agentArns</a> -
--   ARNs of the agents to use for an NFS location.
newOnPremConfig :: NonEmpty Text -> OnPremConfig

-- | Represents the options that are available to control the behavior of a
--   <a>StartTaskExecution</a> operation. Behavior includes preserving
--   metadata such as user ID (UID), group ID (GID), and file permissions,
--   and also overwriting files in the destination, data integrity
--   verification, and so on.
--   
--   A task has a set of default options associated with it. If you don't
--   specify an option in <a>StartTaskExecution</a>, the default value is
--   used. You can override the defaults options on each task execution by
--   specifying an overriding <tt>Options</tt> value to
--   <a>StartTaskExecution</a>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newOptions</a> smart constructor.
data Options
Options' :: Maybe Atime -> Maybe VerifyMode -> Maybe TaskQueueing -> Maybe LogLevel -> Maybe PosixPermissions -> Maybe Mtime -> Maybe Uid -> Maybe Integer -> Maybe SmbSecurityDescriptorCopyFlags -> Maybe Gid -> Maybe OverwriteMode -> Maybe TransferMode -> Maybe PreserveDeletedFiles -> Maybe PreserveDevices -> Options

-- | Create a value of <a>Options</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:atime:Options'</a>, <a>options_atime</a> - A file metadata
--   value that shows the last time a file was accessed (that is, when the
--   file was read or written to). If you set <tt>Atime</tt> to
--   BEST_EFFORT, DataSync attempts to preserve the original <tt>Atime</tt>
--   attribute on all source files (that is, the version before the
--   PREPARING phase). However, <tt>Atime</tt>'s behavior is not fully
--   standard across platforms, so DataSync can only do this on a
--   best-effort basis.
--   
--   Default value: BEST_EFFORT.
--   
--   BEST_EFFORT: Attempt to preserve the per-file <tt>Atime</tt> value
--   (recommended).
--   
--   NONE: Ignore <tt>Atime</tt>.
--   
--   If <tt>Atime</tt> is set to BEST_EFFORT, <tt>Mtime</tt> must be set to
--   PRESERVE.
--   
--   If <tt>Atime</tt> is set to NONE, <tt>Mtime</tt> must also be NONE.
--   
--   <a>$sel:verifyMode:Options'</a>, <a>options_verifyMode</a> - A value
--   that determines whether a data integrity verification should be
--   performed at the end of a task execution after all data and metadata
--   have been transferred. For more information, see <a>Configure task
--   settings</a>.
--   
--   Default value: POINT_IN_TIME_CONSISTENT.
--   
--   ONLY_FILES_TRANSFERRED (recommended): Perform verification only on
--   files that were transferred.
--   
--   POINT_IN_TIME_CONSISTENT: Scan the entire source and entire
--   destination at the end of the transfer to verify that source and
--   destination are fully synchronized. This option isn't supported when
--   transferring to S3 Glacier or S3 Glacier Deep Archive storage classes.
--   
--   NONE: No additional verification is done at the end of the transfer,
--   but all data transmissions are integrity-checked with checksum
--   verification during the transfer.
--   
--   <a>$sel:taskQueueing:Options'</a>, <a>options_taskQueueing</a> - A
--   value that determines whether tasks should be queued before executing
--   the tasks. If set to <tt>ENABLED</tt>, the tasks will be queued. The
--   default is <tt>ENABLED</tt>.
--   
--   If you use the same agent to run multiple tasks, you can enable the
--   tasks to run in series. For more information, see <a>Queueing task
--   executions</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:logLevel:Options'</a>, <a>options_logLevel</a> - A value that
--   determines the type of logs that DataSync publishes to a log stream in
--   the Amazon CloudWatch log group that you provide. For more information
--   about providing a log group for DataSync, see
--   <a>CloudWatchLogGroupArn</a>. If set to <tt>OFF</tt>, no logs are
--   published. <tt>BASIC</tt> publishes logs on errors for individual
--   files transferred, and <tt>TRANSFER</tt> publishes logs for every file
--   or object that is transferred and integrity checked.
--   
--   <a>$sel:posixPermissions:Options'</a>, <a>options_posixPermissions</a>
--   - A value that determines which users or groups can access a file for
--   a specific purpose such as reading, writing, or execution of the file.
--   This option should only be set for NFS, EFS, and S3 locations. For
--   more information about what metadata is copied by DataSync, see
--   <a>Metadata Copied by DataSync</a>.
--   
--   Default value: PRESERVE.
--   
--   PRESERVE: Preserve POSIX-style permissions (recommended).
--   
--   NONE: Ignore permissions.
--   
--   DataSync can preserve extant permissions of a source location.
--   
--   <a>$sel:mtime:Options'</a>, <a>options_mtime</a> - A value that
--   indicates the last time that a file was modified (that is, a file was
--   written to) before the PREPARING phase. This option is required for
--   cases when you need to run the same task more than one time.
--   
--   Default value: PRESERVE.
--   
--   PRESERVE: Preserve original <tt>Mtime</tt> (recommended)
--   
--   NONE: Ignore <tt>Mtime</tt>.
--   
--   If <tt>Mtime</tt> is set to PRESERVE, <tt>Atime</tt> must be set to
--   BEST_EFFORT.
--   
--   If <tt>Mtime</tt> is set to NONE, <tt>Atime</tt> must also be set to
--   NONE.
--   
--   <a>$sel:uid:Options'</a>, <a>options_uid</a> - The POSIX user ID (UID)
--   of the file's owner. This option should only be set for NFS, EFS, and
--   S3 locations. To learn more about what metadata is copied by DataSync,
--   see <a>Metadata Copied by DataSync</a>.
--   
--   Default value: INT_VALUE. This preserves the integer value of the ID.
--   
--   INT_VALUE: Preserve the integer value of UID and group ID (GID)
--   (recommended).
--   
--   NONE: Ignore UID and GID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bytesPerSecond:Options'</a>, <a>options_bytesPerSecond</a> - A
--   value that limits the bandwidth used by DataSync. For example, if you
--   want DataSync to use a maximum of 1 MB, set this value to
--   <tt>1048576</tt> (<tt>=1024*1024</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:securityDescriptorCopyFlags:Options'</a>,
--   <a>options_securityDescriptorCopyFlags</a> - A value that determines
--   which components of the SMB security descriptor are copied from source
--   to destination objects.
--   
--   This value is only used for transfers between SMB and Amazon FSx for
--   Windows File Server locations, or between two Amazon FSx for Windows
--   File Server locations. For more information about how DataSync handles
--   metadata, see <a>How DataSync Handles Metadata and Special Files</a>.
--   
--   Default value: OWNER_DACL.
--   
--   <b>OWNER_DACL</b>: For each copied object, DataSync copies the
--   following metadata:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Object owner.</li>
--   <li>NTFS discretionary access control lists (DACLs), which determine
--   whether to grant access to an object.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   When choosing this option, DataSync does NOT copy the NTFS system
--   access control lists (SACLs), which are used by administrators to log
--   attempts to access a secured object.
--   
--   <b>OWNER_DACL_SACL</b>: For each copied object, DataSync copies the
--   following metadata:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Object owner.</li>
--   <li>NTFS discretionary access control lists (DACLs), which determine
--   whether to grant access to an object.</li>
--   <li>NTFS system access control lists (SACLs), which are used by
--   administrators to log attempts to access a secured object.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   Copying SACLs requires granting additional permissions to the Windows
--   user that DataSync uses to access your SMB location. For information
--   about choosing a user that ensures sufficient permissions to files,
--   folders, and metadata, see <a>user</a>.
--   
--   <b>NONE</b>: None of the SMB security descriptor components are
--   copied. Destination objects are owned by the user that was provided
--   for accessing the destination location. DACLs and SACLs are set based
--   on the destination server’s configuration.
--   
--   <a>$sel:gid:Options'</a>, <a>options_gid</a> - The POSIX group ID
--   (GID) of the file's owners. This option should only be set for NFS,
--   EFS, and S3 locations. For more information about what metadata is
--   copied by DataSync, see <a>Metadata Copied by DataSync</a>.
--   
--   Default value: INT_VALUE. This preserves the integer value of the ID.
--   
--   INT_VALUE: Preserve the integer value of user ID (UID) and GID
--   (recommended).
--   
--   NONE: Ignore UID and GID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:overwriteMode:Options'</a>, <a>options_overwriteMode</a> - A
--   value that determines whether files at the destination should be
--   overwritten or preserved when copying files. If set to <tt>NEVER</tt>
--   a destination file will not be replaced by a source file, even if the
--   destination file differs from the source file. If you modify files in
--   the destination and you sync the files, you can use this value to
--   protect against overwriting those changes.
--   
--   Some storage classes have specific behaviors that can affect your S3
--   storage cost. For detailed information, see <a>Considerations when
--   working with Amazon S3 storage classes in DataSync</a> in the
--   <i>DataSync User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:transferMode:Options'</a>, <a>options_transferMode</a> - A
--   value that determines whether DataSync transfers only the data and
--   metadata that differ between the source and the destination location,
--   or whether DataSync transfers all the content from the source, without
--   comparing to the destination location.
--   
--   CHANGED: DataSync copies only data or metadata that is new or
--   different content from the source location to the destination
--   location.
--   
--   ALL: DataSync copies all source location content to the destination,
--   without comparing to existing content on the destination.
--   
--   <a>$sel:preserveDeletedFiles:Options'</a>,
--   <a>options_preserveDeletedFiles</a> - A value that specifies whether
--   files in the destination that don't exist in the source file system
--   should be preserved. This option can affect your storage cost. If your
--   task deletes objects, you might incur minimum storage duration charges
--   for certain storage classes. For detailed information, see
--   <a>Considerations when working with Amazon S3 storage classes in
--   DataSync</a> in the <i>DataSync User Guide</i>.
--   
--   Default value: PRESERVE.
--   
--   PRESERVE: Ignore such destination files (recommended).
--   
--   REMOVE: Delete destination files that aren’t present in the source.
--   
--   <a>$sel:preserveDevices:Options'</a>, <a>options_preserveDevices</a> -
--   A value that determines whether DataSync should preserve the metadata
--   of block and character devices in the source file system, and
--   re-create the files with that device name and metadata on the
--   destination. DataSync does not copy the contents of such devices, only
--   the name and metadata.
--   
--   DataSync can't sync the actual contents of such devices, because they
--   are nonterminal and don't return an end-of-file (EOF) marker.
--   
--   Default value: NONE.
--   
--   NONE: Ignore special devices (recommended).
--   
--   PRESERVE: Preserve character and block device metadata. This option
--   isn't currently supported for Amazon EFS.
newOptions :: Options

-- | The VPC endpoint, subnet, and security group that an agent uses to
--   access IP addresses in a VPC (Virtual Private Cloud).
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPrivateLinkConfig</a> smart constructor.
data PrivateLinkConfig
PrivateLinkConfig' :: Maybe (NonEmpty Text) -> Maybe (NonEmpty Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> PrivateLinkConfig

-- | Create a value of <a>PrivateLinkConfig</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:securityGroupArns:PrivateLinkConfig'</a>,
--   <a>privateLinkConfig_securityGroupArns</a> - The Amazon Resource Names
--   (ARNs) of the security groups that are configured for the EC2 resource
--   that hosts an agent activated in a VPC or an agent that has access to
--   a VPC endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subnetArns:PrivateLinkConfig'</a>,
--   <a>privateLinkConfig_subnetArns</a> - The Amazon Resource Names (ARNs)
--   of the subnets that are configured for an agent activated in a VPC or
--   an agent that has access to a VPC endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:privateLinkEndpoint:PrivateLinkConfig'</a>,
--   <a>privateLinkConfig_privateLinkEndpoint</a> - The private endpoint
--   that is configured for an agent that has access to IP addresses in a
--   <a>PrivateLink</a>. An agent that is configured with this endpoint
--   will not be accessible over the public internet.
--   
--   <a>$sel:vpcEndpointId:PrivateLinkConfig'</a>,
--   <a>privateLinkConfig_vpcEndpointId</a> - The ID of the VPC endpoint
--   that is configured for an agent. An agent that is configured with a
--   VPC endpoint will not be accessible over the public internet.
newPrivateLinkConfig :: PrivateLinkConfig

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Identity and Access Management
--   (IAM) role that is used to access an Amazon S3 bucket.
--   
--   For detailed information about using such a role, see Creating a
--   Location for Amazon S3 in the <i>DataSync User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newS3Config</a> smart constructor.
data S3Config
S3Config' :: Text -> S3Config

-- | Create a value of <a>S3Config</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:bucketAccessRoleArn:S3Config'</a>,
--   <a>s3Config_bucketAccessRoleArn</a> - The Amazon S3 bucket to access.
--   This bucket is used as a parameter in the <a>CreateLocationS3</a>
--   operation.
newS3Config :: Text -> S3Config

-- | Represents the mount options that are available for DataSync to access
--   an SMB location.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSmbMountOptions</a> smart constructor.
data SmbMountOptions
SmbMountOptions' :: Maybe SmbVersion -> SmbMountOptions

-- | Create a value of <a>SmbMountOptions</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:version:SmbMountOptions'</a>, <a>smbMountOptions_version</a> -
--   The specific SMB version that you want DataSync to use to mount your
--   SMB share. If you don't specify a version, DataSync defaults to
--   <tt>AUTOMATIC</tt>. That is, DataSync automatically selects a version
--   based on negotiation with the SMB server.
newSmbMountOptions :: SmbMountOptions

-- | Represents a single entry in a list of AWS resource tags.
--   <tt>TagListEntry</tt> returns an array that contains a list of tasks
--   when the <a>ListTagsForResource</a> operation is called.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTagListEntry</a> smart constructor.
data TagListEntry
TagListEntry' :: Maybe Text -> Text -> TagListEntry

-- | Create a value of <a>TagListEntry</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:value:TagListEntry'</a>, <a>tagListEntry_value</a> - The value
--   for an Amazon Web Services resource tag.
--   
--   <a>$sel:key:TagListEntry'</a>, <a>tagListEntry_key</a> - The key for
--   an Amazon Web Services resource tag.
newTagListEntry :: Text -> TagListEntry

-- | Represents a single entry in a list of task executions.
--   <tt>TaskExecutionListEntry</tt> returns an array that contains a list
--   of specific invocations of a task when the <a>ListTaskExecutions</a>
--   operation is called.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTaskExecutionListEntry</a> smart constructor.
data TaskExecutionListEntry
TaskExecutionListEntry' :: Maybe TaskExecutionStatus -> Maybe Text -> TaskExecutionListEntry

-- | Create a value of <a>TaskExecutionListEntry</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:TaskExecutionListEntry'</a>,
--   <a>taskExecutionListEntry_status</a> - The status of a task execution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:taskExecutionArn:TaskExecutionListEntry'</a>,
--   <a>taskExecutionListEntry_taskExecutionArn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the task that was executed.
newTaskExecutionListEntry :: TaskExecutionListEntry

-- | Describes the detailed result of a <tt>TaskExecution</tt> operation.
--   This result includes the time in milliseconds spent in each phase, the
--   status of the task execution, and the errors encountered.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTaskExecutionResultDetail</a> smart constructor.
data TaskExecutionResultDetail
TaskExecutionResultDetail' :: Maybe Natural -> Maybe PhaseStatus -> Maybe PhaseStatus -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe PhaseStatus -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Text -> TaskExecutionResultDetail

-- | Create a value of <a>TaskExecutionResultDetail</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:prepareDuration:TaskExecutionResultDetail'</a>,
--   <a>taskExecutionResultDetail_prepareDuration</a> - The total time in
--   milliseconds that DataSync spent in the PREPARING phase.
--   
--   <a>$sel:prepareStatus:TaskExecutionResultDetail'</a>,
--   <a>taskExecutionResultDetail_prepareStatus</a> - The status of the
--   PREPARING phase.
--   
--   <a>$sel:verifyStatus:TaskExecutionResultDetail'</a>,
--   <a>taskExecutionResultDetail_verifyStatus</a> - The status of the
--   VERIFYING phase.
--   
--   <a>$sel:verifyDuration:TaskExecutionResultDetail'</a>,
--   <a>taskExecutionResultDetail_verifyDuration</a> - The total time in
--   milliseconds that DataSync spent in the VERIFYING phase.
--   
--   <a>$sel:totalDuration:TaskExecutionResultDetail'</a>,
--   <a>taskExecutionResultDetail_totalDuration</a> - The total time in
--   milliseconds that DataSync took to transfer the file from the source
--   to the destination location.
--   
--   <a>$sel:transferStatus:TaskExecutionResultDetail'</a>,
--   <a>taskExecutionResultDetail_transferStatus</a> - The status of the
--   TRANSFERRING phase.
--   
--   <a>$sel:errorCode:TaskExecutionResultDetail'</a>,
--   <a>taskExecutionResultDetail_errorCode</a> - Errors that DataSync
--   encountered during execution of the task. You can use this error code
--   to help troubleshoot issues.
--   
--   <a>$sel:transferDuration:TaskExecutionResultDetail'</a>,
--   <a>taskExecutionResultDetail_transferDuration</a> - The total time in
--   milliseconds that DataSync spent in the TRANSFERRING phase.
--   
--   <a>$sel:errorDetail:TaskExecutionResultDetail'</a>,
--   <a>taskExecutionResultDetail_errorDetail</a> - Detailed description of
--   an error that was encountered during the task execution. You can use
--   this information to help troubleshoot issues.
newTaskExecutionResultDetail :: TaskExecutionResultDetail

-- | You can use API filters to narrow down the list of resources returned
--   by <tt>ListTasks</tt>. For example, to retrieve all tasks on a source
--   location, you can use <tt>ListTasks</tt> with filter name
--   <tt>LocationId</tt> and <tt>Operator Equals</tt> with the ARN for the
--   location.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTaskFilter</a> smart constructor.
data TaskFilter
TaskFilter' :: TaskFilterName -> [Text] -> Operator -> TaskFilter

-- | Create a value of <a>TaskFilter</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:TaskFilter'</a>, <a>taskFilter_name</a> - The name of the
--   filter being used. Each API call supports a list of filters that are
--   available for it. For example, <tt>LocationId</tt> for
--   <tt>ListTasks</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:values:TaskFilter'</a>, <a>taskFilter_values</a> - The values
--   that you want to filter for. For example, you might want to display
--   only tasks for a specific destination location.
--   
--   <a>$sel:operator:TaskFilter'</a>, <a>taskFilter_operator</a> - The
--   operator that is used to compare filter values (for example,
--   <tt>Equals</tt> or <tt>Contains</tt>). For more about API filtering
--   operators, see <a>API filters for ListTasks and ListLocations</a>.
newTaskFilter :: TaskFilterName -> Operator -> TaskFilter

-- | Represents a single entry in a list of tasks. <tt>TaskListEntry</tt>
--   returns an array that contains a list of tasks when the
--   <a>ListTasks</a> operation is called. A task includes the source and
--   destination file systems to sync and the options to use for the tasks.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTaskListEntry</a> smart constructor.
data TaskListEntry
TaskListEntry' :: Maybe TaskStatus -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> TaskListEntry

-- | Create a value of <a>TaskListEntry</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:TaskListEntry'</a>, <a>taskListEntry_status</a> - The
--   status of the task.
--   
--   <a>$sel:taskArn:TaskListEntry'</a>, <a>taskListEntry_taskArn</a> - The
--   Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the task.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:TaskListEntry'</a>, <a>taskListEntry_name</a> - The name
--   of the task.
newTaskListEntry :: TaskListEntry

-- | Specifies the schedule you want your task to use for repeated
--   executions. For more information, see <a>Schedule Expressions for
--   Rules</a>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTaskSchedule</a> smart constructor.
data TaskSchedule
TaskSchedule' :: Text -> TaskSchedule

-- | Create a value of <a>TaskSchedule</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:scheduleExpression:TaskSchedule'</a>,
--   <a>taskSchedule_scheduleExpression</a> - A cron expression that
--   specifies when DataSync initiates a scheduled transfer from a source
--   to a destination location.
newTaskSchedule :: Text -> TaskSchedule
